name: Comfort Inn Port Fairy

reviews.text: Having spent two days "doing" the Great Ocean Road, I spent one night here before heading into the Grampians.
reviews.title: Good Stopover

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: It was a good decision. The hotel's appearance is a bit cheesy, but the rooms are comfortable and the welcome warm. Location is good too, being handy for the river, coast and town centre.
reviews.title: Above expectations
Nice large room.... Nice village....
reviews.text: The only food I tried was breakfast, but that was good quality and plentiful - just the preparation needed for a morning's long drive.

reviews.title: check this place out
reviews.text: This hotel was recommended to us. We got a room on the ground floor in the new building. We could not believe that this was a Comfort Inn, what a high standard. The room was very spacious, two large beds and very nicely decorated. It had a small patio with two chairs and a table.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We just stayed for one night, but could have easily stayed for many more.
reviews.title: Excellent lodging

reviews.text: Outside it looks like old building but in reality it is very much just a motel. We had two rooms (two couples), same price and next to each other. They were about the same size but style was very different, another was ordinary, modern motelroom; another was motelroom with something which tried to look old traditional, but was mostly funny kitsch.
reviews.title: Rooms can be different

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed January 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Restaurant at the same building is not run by same company. Had to make separate bill.
reviews.title: Not worth rate paid

reviews.text: We had early morning departure and sign told reception is open 0630-, but we had to make several phone calls, finally at 0715 we were able to leave.
reviews.title: Best Bed I have slept in!

likes.liked: — The very large and comfortable bed
likes.disliked: — The internet connect had problems but staff did help as much as they could

reviews.title: Excellent
reviews.text: We paid $165 for Queen Spa room, which I find too expensive for its quality.
Room is spacious and yes there is spa in bathroom, which we didn't use. The furniture and bedding are average. It certainly didn't have the duvet as featured on their website.
reviews.title: Far better the expected

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stopped for one night in Port Fairy whilst driving along the Great Ocean Road, and the Comfort Inn was absolutely fine. The staff on check in were friendly and helpful and our room was big. We had a motel style room, which looked a little dated, but was comfortable and clean.
reviews.title: Good location for seeing Port Fairy

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: There's a free guest laundry available. We didn't use any of the other hotel facilities so can't comment on those. There aren't many parking spaces in the car park, but parking is also free on the street outside.
reviews.title: Smallest room I've ever stayed in

reviews.text: It's easy to walk to the shops/restaurants in Port Fairy from the hotel, and a slightly longer walk takes you down to the Moyne River and along to Griffiths Island - go at dusk and see the wallabies hopping about.
reviews.title: Full of character!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I was stunned when we opened the door to our room at Seacombe. It was honestly just a bed, with almost no room to put our bags down. Zero facilities, and shared bathroom...it felt like a backpacker lodging at hotel prices. Very very overpriced, and much better value is available if you look around
reviews.title: Lovely Hotel - Port Fairy very quiet

reviews.text: We stayed in the old part of this listed building, lots of character. We had a room for the three of us for A$100, inc. breakfast. Not en suite, but as we were the only people upstairs it was no problem. I guess you might have to queue for bathrooms at peak times such as the Easter folk fest. Staff were friendly & we didn't have any trouble with the ghost!
reviews.title: very nice little town

reviews.text: The older part of the Comfort Inn Port Fairy is also known as Secombe House, being an old pub built in 1858 and with a good deal of history behind it. I really enjoyed staying here - the building is incredibly solid with foot-thick walls and hence beautifully quiet, authentic and charming. Be aware however that the stairway and upper level corridors are only about a metre wide, and like many old buildings the timbers have settled in such a way that the floor, while strong, is no longer even. I didn't care to take our larger suitcase up the stairs and instead repacked into our smaller case which was more manageable. Elderly people or anyone a little unsteady on their feet may find the upper level difficult; similarly you wouldn't want to take a stroller or bassinet up these stairs.
reviews.title: Take your own drinking water if staying in Port Fairy

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The room itself was clean and comfortable and the heater was effective which we were glad of. I felt the room lacked colour - the carpet is beige, the walls and blinds are cream, the bedding was modern but oatmeal and the 1940's wardrobe was timber. A splash of colour in the form of the towels or a cushion or two would liven it up a little. But this is a pretty minor point. Our shared bathroom was lovely.
reviews.title: Good value accomadation, great location

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: What really surprised me at this place was that the tap water was undrinkable - I took one mouthful from the bathroom and wished I hadn't. On asking at the front desk I was told that it wouldn't hurt me but that it was 'ground water' - i.e. bore water or artesian water straight from the ground with no filtering. I found it extraordinary that there was no notice about this either on the hotel website or in the bathroom itself. Reception advised that the water wouldn't hurt me - it was free of e-coli - but that as it had very high levels of lime in it most people preferred bottled water - which was available from the hotel at $3 for each 600 ml bottle! This story was confirmed at the Stump Inn where we went to eat, and who again sold bottled water at $3 a pop. If this situation is standard throughout the town, which I understand it is, then I think Port Fairy - and certainly this hotel - are being a bit naughty in keeping this information under their hat. Other places in the area might have rainwater, but barring that there is no town water supply and if you are going there you'd be advised to buy several large bottles or a 5-gallon keg from a supermarket before heading in.
reviews.title: Lovely people, generous, clean room. Everything worked beautifully.

reviews.text: Only other thing is that Stag Restaurant downstairs is truly superb but closed on Tuesdays and Wednesdays for dinner. We had breakfast there though and it was out of this world. Highly recommended. The Stump Inn seems to serve good hearty food in an informal and somewhat idiosyncratic environment - but well worth a visit.
reviews.title: Needed a Rest

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed at Seacombe House, Port Fairy for one night on our way along the Great Ocean Road.
reviews.title: Good Spot in a Quaint Town

description: Select from a range of accommodation options at Comfort Inn Port Fairy and at Seacombe House, circa 1847, in Port Fairy, arguably one of Victoria's most historic and beautiful towns. All situated at the ocean end of the main street in a quiet garden setting, only minutes to the shops, boutiques, cafes and restaurants, five minutes walk to the historic wharf and Moyne River, and ten minutes walk to the beaches.
